title: Biggest box-office flops of the 21st century - including one from Marvel

With massive hits like Avengers making billions of dollars it's not hard to see why Hollywood is big business.

But not every feature film is destined for greatness, with some expensive features losing millions.

MusicMagpie has compiled 1,000 films with budgets of more than £40.9 million to see what are the biggest earners – as well as the biggest losers.

The seven films included in this list represent some of the biggest differences between the budget spent on the movie and the money made back.

7. A Sound of Thunder (2005)

Starring Edward Burns, Catherine McCormack and Ben Kingsley this adaptation of author Ray Bradbury’s short story of the same name cost an estimated £65.46 million to produce.

But it only grossed a paltry £5.16 million worldwide, meaning the film lost an estimated £60.31 million.

6. Renegades (2017)

This action thriller starring Sullivan Stapleton and JK Simmons follows a group of Navy SEALS asked to salvage Nazi gold at the bottom of a Bosnian lake.

The film only grossed a feeble £1.23 million against its £63.42 million budget.

5. The Promise (2017)

The Promise was a historical drama starring Oscar Isaac, Christian Bale and Charlotte Le Bon in a love triangle against the backdrop of the Armenian Genocide.

The film cost £73.65 million to make and only grossed £8.59 million.

According to the studio the purpose of the film was to bring attention to the story, not make money.

4. The Adventures of Pluto Nash (2002)

Starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role, the critically panned sci-fi comedy managed to earn a Razzie nomination for worst film, worst actor, worst director, worst screenplay and worst on-screen couple (both for Eddie Murphy and a cloned version of himself).

It managed to make just £5.73 million on a budget of £81.83 million.

(Image: Warner Bros)

3. Town and Country (2001)

This rom-com Starring Warren Beatty, Diane Keaton, Goldie Hawn and Garry Schandling was plagued by constant reshoots that stretched the initial budget of £36 million to a whopping £85.92 million.

Town and Country only managed to make £8.43 million at the box office and Warren Beatty didn’t appear in another motion picture for 15 years.

2. Dark Phoenix (2019)

With Sophie Turner playing the eponymous star, the latest instalment of the long-running X-Men franchise didn’t share the same success its Marvel counterparts usually enjoy.

After initial test screenings were received poorly, the entire third act of the film was completely reshot contributing to the massive £286.40 million budget.

The film only managed to make £201.54 million back and director Simon Kinberg publicly took responsibility for the poor reception of the film.

1. Mars Needs Moms (2011)

Based on the Berkeley Breathed book of the same title, this 3D animated motion-capture family film from Disney grossed just £32.32 million on a budget of £122.74 million, making it one of the largest financial losses for a film ever recorded.

NB: The budget and gross figures have not been adjusted for inflation. These figures come from The-Numbers.com to collate the financial information, and figures are the same as the listings
description: From Christian Bale to Jennifer Lawrence, there are some big names that went down with these box-office bombs
